newsitem.title: JAPAN: Oracle sees 100 mln network computer sales in 2000.
newsitem.headline: Oracle sees 100 mln network computer sales in 2000.

text.p: Oracle Corp chief executive officer Larry Ellison said on Wednesday he expects sales of network computers in 2000 to reach 100 million units.
This would represent 90 percent of the global market for computers for personal use, he told a news conference in Tokyo.
"Network computers will greatly outsell personal computers (PCs)," he said. "Microsoft will have to deal with competition for the first time."
He said Microsoft Corp's PC software was both complex and expensive in comparison with network computer technology.
Ellison said Oracle and its partners plan to package five client appliances and one server, together with cables, keyboards and other equipment necessary for a complete network for $4,999.
The product would be called "Network in a Box" and cost much less than Microsoft's "Office" brand software, he said.
Ellison said the cost of network computer terminal would range from $295 to $795. The cost of a server would range from $1,495 to $9,999.
A network computer is a stripped-down, low-cost computer that can access the Internet.
Oracle last year formed a new company to promote network computers to challenge PCs.
International Business Machines Corp, Apple Computer Inc, Netscape Communications Corp and Sun Microsystems Inc have expressed support for idea of network computers.
